name: trans-2-Amino-3,3-dimethylcyclobutane-1-carboxylic acid
Reason: Starting with the basic unit cyclobutane, which has a melting point around -90°C. The introduction of functional groups will modify this value significantly. Each methyl group is expected to increase the melting point due to an increase in Van der Waals forces; let's estimate it at +50°C for both. The amino group (-NH2) will contribute to intermolecular hydrogen bonding, which substantially increases melting point; we will estimate this effect at +110°C. Finally, the carboxyl group (-COOH) also establishes strong hydrogen bonding, further increasing the melting point; let's estimate this effect at +85°C. Summing these contributions gives us an estimated overall increase in melting point.
Prediction: (Base cyclobutane: -90) + (2 x methyl groups: +100) + (amino group: +110) + (carboxyl group: +85) = 205°C

name: trans-2-Amino-3,3-dimethylcyclobutane-1-carboxylic acid
Reason: Starting with the basic unit cyclobutane, which has a melting point around -90°C. The introduction of functional groups will significantly increase this value. Each methyl group is expected to raise the melting point, partially due to an increase in van der Waals interactions; let's estimate this effect at +70°C for both methyl groups together. The amino group (-NH2) contributes to intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which usually results in a significant melting point increase; we will estimate this effect at +100°C. The carboxyl group (-COOH) forms strong hydrogen bonds, which typically increases melting points significantly; this effect can be estimated at +75°C. Adding these contributions together should give us the predicted melting point.
Prediction: (Base cyclobutane: -90) + (2 x methyl groups: +70) + (amino group: +100) + (carboxyl group: +75) = 155°C
